subject: linear_algebra
title: Diagonalization of Matrices
contentHtml:
When possible, a matrix can be diagonalized by finding its eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

This process is useful for computing matrix powers efficiently.
name: Diagonalization Formula
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of A.", "mathHtml": "\\[\\lambda_1 = 1.5, \\lambda_2 = -0.5\]", "explanation": "We use standard linear algebra techniques to find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Construct the diagonal matrix D.", "mathHtml": "\\[D = [[1.5, 0], [0, -0.5]]\]", "explanation": "The diagonal elements are the eigenvalues."} ],
intuition: Diagonalization allows us to simplify complex matrix operations by breaking them down into separate scalar multiplications.

title: Diagonalization of Matrices
contentHtml: When possible, a square matrix A can be diagonalized as P⁻¹AP = D, where P is an invertible matrix and D is a diagonal matrix.
name: Diagonalization Formula" },
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of A", "mathHtml": "\[A - \lambda I\] = 0", "explanation": "We need to find the values that make A similar to a diagonal matrix."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Construct the matrix P from the eigenvectors", "mathHtml": "P = [eigenvector1, ..., eigenvectork]", "explanation": "The columns of P are the eigenvectors of A."} ],
intuition: Diagonalization is useful when we need to compute matrix powers or exponentials. By diagonalizing a matrix, we can simplify these computations.
